message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: cvc5: A Versatile and Industrial-Strength SMT Solver
Paper Abstract: Abstract cvc5 is the latest SMT solver in the cooperating validity checker series and builds on the successful code base of CVC4. This paper serves as a comprehensive system description of cvc5 ’s architectural design and highlights the major features and components introduced since CVC4 1.8. We evaluate cvc5 ’s performance on all benchmarks in SMT-LIB and provide a comparison against CVC4 and Z3.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "SMT-LIB benchmark"

Links: [{"title":"Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability_modulo_theories"},{"title":"Simultaneous multithreading - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_multithreading"},{"title":"Alt-Ergo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alt-Ergo"},{"title":"Language model benchmark - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model_benchmark"},{"title":"Hyper-threading - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper-threading"},{"title":"Statistical machine translation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_machine_translation"},{"title":"Benchmark (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benchmark_(computing)"},{"title":"SMT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMT"},{"title":"Comparison of different machine translation approaches - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_different_machine_translation_approaches"},{"title":"Standard Template Library - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Template_Library"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about SMT-LIB benchmark:

SMT-LIB is a prominent standard that provides a language based on S-expressions for standardizing the interface to SMT solvers. The SMT-LIB language indicates compatibility, though many systems marked as compatible may support only older versions of SMT-LIB or offer only partial support for the language.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Z3 theorem prover and Microsoft:

Z3, also known as the Z3 Theorem Prover, is a satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solver developed by Microsoft.(no content)Z3 was developed in the Research in Software Engineering (RiSE) group at Microsoft Research Redmond and is targeted at solving problems that arise in software verification and program analysis.(no content)Z3 supports arithmetic, fixed-size bit-vectors, extensional arrays, datatypes, uninterpreted functions, and quantifiers.(no content)Its main applications are extended static checking, test case generation, and predicate abstraction.(no content)Z3 was open sourced in the beginning of 2015. The source code is licensed under MIT License and hosted on GitHub.(no content)It has officially supported bindings for several programming languages, including C, C++, Python, .NET, Java, and OCaml.

Z3 has received significant recognition in the field: In 2015, Z3 received the Programming Languages Software Award from ACM SIGPLAN.(no content)Microsoft researchers Nikolaj Bjørner and Leonardo de Moura received the 2019 Herbrand Award for Distinguished Contributions to Automated Reasoning in recognition of their work in advancing theorem proving with Z3.

Web search results for query: "CVC4 SMT solver"

Links: [{"title":"Cooperating Validity Checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperating_Validity_Checker"},{"title":"Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability_modulo_theories"},{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"Maximum satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"Expected linear time MST algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_linear_time_MST_algorithm"},{"title":"Continuously variable slope delta modulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuously_variable_slope_delta_modulation"},{"title":"Electromagnetic field solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_field_solver"},{"title":"CV4 technique - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CV4_technique"},{"title":"Cell division control protein 4 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cell_division_control_protein_4"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about CVC4:

## Overview

CVC4 (Cooperating Validity Checker) is a satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solver. It is one of the latest major versions of the CVC family, alongside CVC5, with earlier versions including CVC, CVC Lite, and CVC3.

## Features and Capabilities

CVC4 supports the SMT-LIB and TPTP input formats for solving SMT problems, and the SyGuS-IF format for program synthesis. CVC4 can output proofs that can be independently checked in the LFSC format.

CVC4 uses the DPLL(T) architecture, and supports the theories of linear arithmetic over rationals and integers, fixed-width bitvectors, floating-point arithmetic, strings, (co)-datatypes, sequences, and finite sets.

## Applications and Integration

CVC4 has been applied to the synthesis of recursive programs and to the verification of Amazon Web Services access policies. CVC4 and cvc5 have been integrated with Rocq and Isabelle (which are proof assistants).

## Competition History

CVC4 competed in SMT-COMP in the years 2014-2020, and in SyGuS-COMP in the years 2015-2019, and in CASC in 2013-2015.

Web search results for query: "SMT Solver satisfiability modulo theories"

Links: [{"title":"Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability_modulo_theories"},{"title":"Z3 Theorem Prover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z3_Theorem_Prover"},{"title":"Talk:Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Satisfiability_Modulo_Theories"},{"title":"Cooperating Validity Checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CVC_(theorem_prover)"},{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_solving"},{"title":"DPLL(T) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DPLL(T)"},{"title":"Category:Satisfiability problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Satisfiability_problems"},{"title":"Satisfiability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability"}]

## Search Results: SMT Solver - Satisfiability Modulo Theories

Based on the web search, here's comprehensive information about SMT solvers and satisfiability modulo theories:

### Definition and Overview

Satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) is the problem of determining whether a mathematical formula is satisfiable.(no content)It generalizes the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT) to more complex formulas involving real numbers, integers, and/or various data structures such as lists, arrays, bit vectors, and strings.

### How SMT Works

SMT solvers are tools that aim to solve the SMT problem for a practical subset of inputs.(no content)DPLL(T) is a framework for determining the satisfiability of SMT problems, extending the original SAT-solving DPLL algorithm with the ability to reason about an arbitrary theory T.

### Applications

SMT solvers such as Z3 and cvc5 have been used as a building block for a wide range of applications across computer science, including in automated theorem proving, program analysis, program verification, and software testing.

### Popular SMT Solvers

- **Z3**: Z3, also known as the Z3 Theorem Prover, is a satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solver developed by Microsoft and targeted at solving problems that arise in software verification and program analysis.

- **CVC**: Cooperating Validity Checker (CVC) is a family of satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.

### Supported Theories

Linear inequalities over real variables are evaluated using the rules of the theory of linear real arithmetic, whereas other theories include the theories of arrays and list structures (useful for modeling and verifying computer programs), and the theory of bit vectors (useful in modeling and verifying hardware designs).

### Complexity

Since Boolean satisfiability is already NP-complete, the SMT problem is typically NP-hard, and for many theories it is undecidable.

## Search Results: SMT Solver - Satisfiability Modulo Theories

Based on the web search, here's comprehensive information about SMT solvers and satisfiability modulo theories:

### Definition and Overview

Satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) is the problem of determining whether a mathematical formula is satisfiable.(no content)It generalizes the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT) to more complex formulas involving real numbers, integers, and/or various data structures such as lists, arrays, bit vectors, and strings.

### How SMT Works

SMT solvers are tools that aim to solve the SMT problem for a practical subset of inputs.(no content)DPLL(T) is a framework for determining the satisfiability of SMT problems, extending the original SAT-solving DPLL algorithm with the ability to reason about an arbitrary theory T.

### Applications

SMT solvers such as Z3 and cvc5 have been used as a building block for a wide range of applications across computer science, including in automated theorem proving, program analysis, program verification, and software testing.

### Popular SMT Solvers

- **Z3**: Z3, also known as the Z3 Theorem Prover, is a satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solver developed by Microsoft and targeted at solving problems that arise in software verification and program analysis.

- **CVC**: Cooperating Validity Checker (CVC) is a family of satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.

### Supported Theories

Linear inequalities over real variables are evaluated using the rules of the theory of linear real arithmetic, whereas other theories include the theories of arrays and list structures (useful for modeling and verifying computer programs), and the theory of bit vectors (useful in modeling and verifying hardware designs).

### Complexity

Since Boolean satisfiability is already NP-complete, the SMT problem is typically NP-hard, and for many theories it is undecidable.

Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the cvc5 paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (cvc5 is a new SMT solver with novel architectural design)

**Extracted Triples:**

1. **Satisfiability modulo theories** (task)
   - Relation: proposes
   - Relevance: cvc5 is an SMT solver that addresses the core task of determining satisfiability of mathematical formulas modulo theories.

2. **Cooperating Validity Checker** (artifact)
   - Relation: uses
   - Relevance: cvc5 builds directly on CVC4 from the Cooperating Validity Checker family of SMT solvers.

3. **Z3 Theorem Prover** (tool)
   - Relation: uses
   - Relevance: The paper evaluates cvc5's performance against Z3, a competing SMT solver developed by Microsoft.

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED

All triples have been validated and the JSON file has been updated with correct Wikipedia URLs and comprehensive relevance descriptions.

- [Z3 Theorem Prover - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z3_Theorem_Prover)
- [Cooperating Validity Checker - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperating_Validity_Checker)
